chapter: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 1: A 3-day-old child is suspected to have an inborn error of metabolism. Further evaluation 
reveals elevated blood ammonia in the presence of normal blood pH and bicarbonate levels. 
There are no ketone bodies in the urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
In this case, hyperammonemia is +ve; acidosis is -ve; and ketosis is -ve: This is consistent with 
the urea cycle defect. 269 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 2: A young infant started seizing in his cradle. He was immediately rushed to the casualty. On 
investigation, blood ammonia was markedly elevated. Which of the following is used to lower 
the ammonia levels?
questions.explanation:
All of the above agents are used in the treatment of acute hyperammonemia in an infant. Treatment of acute hyperammonemia in an infant: • Provide adequate calories, fluid, and electrolytes intravenously. • Minimal amounts of protein as a mixture of essential amino acids during the first 24 hours of 
therapy. • Give priming doses of the following compounds: Sodium benzoate, Sodium 
phenylacetate, Arginine hydrochloride. • Initiate peritoneal dialysis or hemodialysis if the above treatment fails to produce an appreciable 
decrease in plasma ammonia levels. Benzoate forms hippurate with endogenous glycine in the liver. Each mole of benzoate removes 1 
mole of ammonia as glycine. Phenylacetate conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine, which is readily excreted 
in the urine. One mole of phenylacetate removes 2 moles of ammonia as glutamine from the body. Arginine administration supplies the urea cycle with ornithine. It is effective in all patients, except 
those with arginase deficiency. Note: Phenylbutyrate which is metabolized to phenylacetate in our body can also be used as it scavenges 
nitrogen.
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 3: An infant's mother is distressed that her baby refuses her feeds and starts vomiting 
immediately when fed and becomes lethargic. After thorough investigations, the baby is 
diagnosed with HHH syndrome. Which of the following is least likely to be found?
questions.explanation:
Hyperuricemia is not a component of HHH syndrome HHH syndrome is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder caused by a defect in the transport system 
of ornithine from the cytosol into the mitochondria (deficiency of ornithine 
permease/translocase), resulting in the accumulation of ornithine in the cytosol leading to 
hyperornithinemia and a deficiency of this amino acid in mitochondria results in the disruption of 
the urea cycle and hyperammonemia. Homocitrulline is formed from the reaction of 
mitochondrial carbamyl phosphate with lysine, which can become a substrate for the OTC 
reaction when ornithine is deficient. Components of HHH syndrome: • Hyperammonemia • Hyperornithinemia • Homocitrullinemia 270 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 4: As a geneticist studying the familial inheritance of porphyrias, which of the following is likely 
to show the inheritance pattern given below?
questions.explanation:
The given pedigree chart shows X-linked dominant inheritance. X-linked protoporphyria is 
inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern. All porphyrias are autosomal dominant except the following : • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (CEP) (autosomal recessive) • -Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase porphyria (ADP) (autosomal recessive) • Protoporphyria - X-linked protoporphyria (X-linked dominant) • Erythropoietic protoporphyria (EPP) (autosomal recessive)
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question: Question 5: The most common porphyria which manifests in childhood is
questions.explanation:
Erythropoietic protoporphyria (autosomal recessive) is the most common porphyria to manifest in 
childhood. Porphyria cutanea tarda (option A) manifests in adults. Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (option B) also known as Günther disease presents itself in 
utero or in infancy. It is a rare autosomal-recessive disease. Hereditary coproporphyria (option D) presents itself in the post-pubertal age.
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following is also known as plumboporphyria due to its clinical similarity to lead 
poisoning?
questions.explanation:
-Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase porphyria (ALAD) is also called plumboporphyria/Doss 
porphyria due to its clinical similarity to lead poisoning, although it is not related to lead 
exposure. ALAD catalyzes the condensation of 2 molecules of ALA to form the pyrrole porphobilinogen 
(PBG). The enzyme is subject to inhibition by lead because ALAD is the principal lead-binding 
protein in erythrocytes, and lead can displace the zinc atoms of the enzyme, thus inhibiting it. 
Therefore, both lead poisoning and ALAD porphyria produce similar signs and 
symptoms. Symptoms resemble those of other acute porphyrias, including acute attacks of 
abdominal pain and neuropathy.
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 7: A 16-year-old girl was admitted for severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. 
She developed generalized seizures in the hospital for which she was given phenytoin. Her 
symptoms worsened, she developed muscle weakness which progressed to quadriparesis. 
Urinary porphobilinogen was found to be high. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis is acute intermittent porphyria which presents as a neurovisceral 
syndrome with no cutaneous manifestations and no phototoxicity. Acute Intermittent Porphyria: • Autosomal dominant • Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase 271 
Sold by @itachibot • Presents at post-pubertal age • Present with hepatic and neurologic manifestations • Exacerbated by P450 inducing drugs like phenytoin, progesterone and dietary restriction
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 8: çou are reading an article titled, ' Dark age vampires or our patients', which describes an 
18-year-old man who has had an intolerance to sunshine since the age of 6. When playing 
cricket he suffered intense burning, redness, swelling, and crusting of knees unprotected by 
shorts, with similar changes on cheeks and bridge of the nose. His labs showed elevated 
concentrations of total erythrocyte protoporphyrin. Which of the following enzyme 
deficiencies can explain this boy's condition?
questions.explanation:
Symptoms of cutaneous photosensitivity beginning in childhood and a substantially elevated 
concentration of total erythrocyte protoporphyrin supports a diagnosis of erythropoietic 
protoporphyria. The enzyme deficient in erythropoietic protoporphyria is ferrochelatase (FECH). Symptoms consist of acute pain and itching often occurring within minutes of sunlight exposure 
and followed by redness and swelling with continued exposure. Swelling may resemble 
angioneurotic edema and solar urticaria. Symptoms are usually worse in the spring and summer. 
Chronic changes may include lichenification, leathery pseudovesicles, labial grooving, and nail 
changes, but changes in pigmentation and pronounced scarring are unusual. Life-threatening protoporphyric hepatopathy is characterized by greater increases in erythrocyte 
and plasma protoporphyrin levels, increased photosensitivity, and either chronically abnormal 
liver function tests or rapidly progressive hepatic failure.
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 9: A 6-month-old baby boy has coarse facial features, cloudy corneas, and gingival hypertrophy. 
He has no neck control and is unable to roll over. Laboratory investigations reveal markedly 
reduced activity of N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase activity in WBCs. What is the 
most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of I-cell disease or inclusion cell disease. It is also 
known as type II Mucolipidosis. It is an autosomal recessive inherited as a lysosomal storage disorder. It is caused due to a defect 
in N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase required for the Golgi to phosphorylate mannose 
residues on glycoproteins. This leads to defective mannose-6-phosphate, an important cell 
signaling molecule required for trafficking of the lysosomal enzyme from the site of its production 
in the endoplasmic reticulum to the lysosome. Due to this defect, the lysosomal enzymes are 
secreted out of the cell and there is an increased serum concentration of the same. Intracellularly, 
there are abnormal inclusion bodies and vacuolizations, thus earning the disease its name. Clinically, these patients present with symptoms either at birth or early in life with growth 
retardation, failure to thrive, delay of developmental milestones, coarse facial features with a 
cloudy cornea and gingival hypertrophy, and other non-specific findings such as hip dislocations, 
inguinal hernias, hepatomegaly, joint limitation, and skin changes. Investigations to establish a diagnosis may include 
measuring N-acetylglucosaminyl-1-phosphotransferase activity in WBCs or in cultured fibroblasts 
and estimating serum levels of lysosomal enzymes. Option B: Galactosemia is caused due to the complete absence of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl 
transferase. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to an inability to convert galactose-1-phosphate 
(galactose-1-P) to uridine diphosphate galactose. It is characterized by typical clinical features 
such as jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, poor feeding, lethargy, diarrhea, 
E.Coli sepsis. Infants may also have edema, ascites, full fontanelle, encephalopathy, and excessive 272 
Sold by @itachibot bruising and bleeding. They tend to develop cataracts due to the accumulation of galactitol. Option C: Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder of -oxidation of fatty acids. 
There is a very large chain fatty acids buildup in the adrenal glands, the white matter of the brain, 
and testes. It is a progressive disease that can lead to adrenal gland crisis, coma, and death. Option D: Hurler syndrome is an important diagnosis in a patient presenting with clinical features 
given in this clinical vignette. But it is a mucopolysaccharidosis type 1-H caused due by the defect 
in the -L Iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparin sulfate and dermatan sulfate. It is 
characterized by skeletal abnormalities, hepatosplenomegaly, and severe intellectual disability. 
Infants develop characteristic coarse facial features, a wide nasal bridge, and a flattened midface. 
Features such as hepatosplenomegaly, umbilical or inguinal hernias, and typical skeletal 
abnormalities, known as dysostosis multiplex laos are also seen. They also have developmental 
delays and recurrent sinopulmonary diseases. Failure to thrive and growth restriction are also 
seen.
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 10: An 8-year-old boy is brought with complaints of severe pain in his right thigh which has 
progressively worsened over the last few months. He is unable to walk because of the same. 
His mother also says he has had repeated nose bleeds in the last few months and the child 
has stopped playing with his friends as he gets easily tired for a month. Physical examination 
reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and anemia. An assay of 
peripheral blood leucocytes shows low levels of beta-glucosidase. What is the inheritance 
pattern of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of bone pain, epistaxis, hepatosplenomegaly, and low levels 
of -glucosidase suggests a diagnosis of Gaucher's disease that is inherited in an autosomal 
recessive pattern. Gaucher's disease: • It is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase 
(-glucosidase) that leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in the lysosomes of cells. • It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder. • The clinical features result from the accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the spleen, 
liver, bone marrow, bone, and other tissues. • There are 3 clinical subtypes, delineated by the absence or presence and progression of 
neurologic manifestations: type 1, or the adult, nonneuronopathic form; type 2, the infantile or 
acute neuronopathic form; and type 3, the juvenile or subacute neuronopathic form • Typical clinical features include delayed puberty, painless hepatomegaly and splenomegaly, liver 
cirrhosis, hypersplenism and pancytopenia, bleeding tendencies, bone pain due to avascular 
necrosis, osteoporosis, pathological fractures. • Neurological symptoms such as developmental delay, hypertonia, strabismus, supranuclear gaze 
palsy (seen in type 3). • Bone marrow examination usually reveals the presence of Gaucher cells (have a 
characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance) • Enzyme replacement therapy for Gaucher's disease: imiglucerase, velaglucerase 
alfa, taliglucerase alfa,eliglustat
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 11: A 6-month-old infant with progressive failure to thrive and milestone regression is being 
evaluated for an inborn error of metabolism. On examination, hypotonia, apathy, deafness, 
hepatosplenomegaly, and generalized lymphadenopathy are present. Fundus examination is 
shown below. A liver biopsy shows foamy hepatocytes loaded with sphingomyelin. Electron 
microscopy reveals zebra bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? 263 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
273 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical vignette along with the cherry-red spot on fundus examination suggests a diagnosis of 
Niemann-Pick disease type A- Lysosomal storage disorder due to an inherited deficiency of 
sphingomyelinase Type A is a severe infantile form with extensive neurologic involvement (hypotonia, milestone 
regression, apathy), marked visceral accumulations of sphingomyelin (hepatosplenomegaly, foamy 
hepatocytes, zebra bodies on EM), and progressive wasting and early death within the first 3 years 
of life. In contrast, patients with Niemann-Pick disease type B have organomegaly but generally no CNS 
involvement.
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 12: A male child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips with hepatosplenomegaly presents 
with copious mucous discharge from the nose. The most probable underlying diagnosis is
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of a child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips, 
hepatosplenomegaly, and copious discharge from the nose is suggestive of Hurler's disease. It is the severe form of mucopolysaccharidoses type 1 (MPS 1), an autosomal recessive disorder 
caused by a defect in -L iduronidase, leading to the accumulation of heparan sulfate and 
dermatan sulfate. The child usually presents between 6 and 24 months with hepatosplenomegaly, 
coarse facial features (shown below), corneal clouding, large tongue, prominent forehead, joint 
stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia. Most patients have recurrent upper respiratory tract and ear infections, noisy breathing, and 
persistent copious nasal discharge. Radiograph shows skeletal dysplasia, called dysostosis 
multiplex - thick ribs, ovoid vertebral bodies, enlarged and trabeculated diaphyses of the long 
bones with irregular metaphysis and epiphysis. Macrocephaly, enlarged J-shaped sella, premature closure of lambdoid sagittal sutures, and 
shallow orbits are seen with disease progression. Obstructive airway disease, cardiac 
complications, and respiratory infections are the common causes of death. The image below shows the radiograph shows enlarged diaphyses of the metacarpal and 
phalanges. 274 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: Option B: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth syndrome characterized by 
macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, omphalocele, and renal anomalies. It is associated 
with an increased risk of Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, neuroblastoma, and 
adrenal cortical carcinoma. Option C: Proteus syndrome is a disturbance of cellular growth involving ectodermal and 
mesodermal tissues, caused by mutation in the AKT1 gene. They present with 
hemimegalencephaly, asymmetric overgrowth of the extremities, verrucous cutaneous lesions, 
thickening of the bone, and excessive growth of muscles. Option D: A child with untreated congenital hypothyroidism may have stunted growth, short 
extremities, narrow palpebral fissures, swollen eyelids, depressed nasal bridge, thick broad 
protruded tongue, and short and thick neck, dry and scaly skin.
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 13: A case series reviews children with lysosomal storage disorders who usually present with 
dysmorphic facies, organomegaly, milestones regression, and failure to thrive. Which of the 
following disorders does not have enzyme replacement therapy as a therapeutic option?
questions.explanation: Enzyme replacement therapy is not available for Sanfilippo syndrome (MPS type III).
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 14: A 3-month-old female child was brought to the clinic with a history of failure to thrive. On 
examination, generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly were present. A chest X-ray image 
shows massive cardiomegaly. A muscle biopsy is performed and the findings are attached in 
the image below. Which of the following is the most likely enzyme that is involved in the 
suspected condition?
questions.explanation:
The muscle biopsy shows the presence of large vacuoles. This along with the clinical vignette is 
strongly suggestive of Pompe's disease or type II glycogen storage disease. It is caused due to the 
deficiency of the enzyme lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase. Clinically, the child presents with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The 
affected child usually dies around the age of 2 years due to heart failure. Investigations include chest X-ray imaging which shows cardiomegaly. The muscle biopsy 
showing vacuoles further aids the diagnosis. Treatment includes enzyme replacement therapy with recombinant enzyme a-glucosidase alfa 
(Myozyme).
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 15: A 6-month-old is brought by his parents with a history of decreased weight gain. On 
examination, you find that the baby has hepatosplenomegaly, muscle weakness and atrophy, 
hypotonia, and decreased deep tendon reflexes. Blood tests reveal normal glucose levels. 
Biopsy of the liver reveals initial stages of cirrhosis due to the accumulation of abnormal 
glycogen with few branch points, whose structure resembles amylopectin. The clinical and 
laboratory results are indicative of which glycogen storage disease?
questions.explanation:
The clinical and laboratory features indicate Andersen's disease in the baby. Inability to gain 
weight, hepatosplenomegaly, muscle weakness, and accumulation of abnormal glycogen 
resembling amylopectin point towards the diagnosis. Andersen's disease is type IV glycogen storage disease. It is transmitted in an autosomal recessive 
pattern and occurs due to a deficiency of glycogen branching enzyme because of pathologic 
variants in the GBE1 gene. This leads to accumulation of of an abnormal structure of glycogen 
known as polyglucosan. It is characterized by 275 
Sold by @itachibot • Growth delay • Hepatomegaly due to the accumulation of polysaccharides with few branch points • Myopathy • There might be fasting intolerance and ketosis in the initial stages. Hypoglycemia usually 
appears late in the disease when it is associated with cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and ascites. • Biopsy of the liver will show the presence of abnormal glycogen which resembles amylopectin. 
Amylopectin is found in plants and has very few branches. Since there is a defect in the branching 
of the glycogen, the abnormal glycogen appears like amylopectin. The diagnosis is confirmed by absent branching enzyme activity in skin fibroblasts, muscle, or 
liver and analysis of the DNA mutation. Von Gierke's disease (Option A) has features of lactic acidosis, hypoglycemia, hyperuricemia, 
impaired growth, and bone thinning. It occurs due to a defect in the glucose 6-phosphatase. McArdle disease (Option C) usually manifests as exercise intolerance, muscle cramping with 
exercise. It is usually a benign chronic condition. It occurs due to a defect in the muscle glycogen 
phosphorylase. Tarui disease (Option D) also presents similar to the McArdle disease. Patients may have 
developmental delay, and hemolytic anemia in addition to exercise-induced muscle cramps. It 
occurs due to a defect in the muscle phosphofructokinase.
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 16: A 6-year-old boy develops hypoglycemia and muscle weakness with moderate activity. On 
examination, he had hepatomegaly and growth restriction. Investigations revealed the 
accumulation of limit dextrins and increased glycogen deposits in the liver. What is the most 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis is Cori disease. Glycogen debrancher deficiency (Glycogen Storage Disease III) is also known as Cori disease, 
Forbes disease, and limit dextrinosis. Cori’s disease may be clinically indistinguishable from von Gierke’s disease in infancy and 
childhood as hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hyperlipidemia, and growth retardation is common. 
Accumulation of limit dextrins is unique to Cori's disease. Definitive diagnosis is through enzyme 
assays in the liver, muscle, or both.
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 17: A 5-day-old neonate is brought to the emergency room with vomiting and poor feeding. 
Breastfeeding was initiated soon after birth. On examination, the child is lethargic and has 
hepatomegaly. Labs reveal increased plasma galactose and increased urine galactitol levels. 
Examination of the mother shows the presence of skin lesions on the breast with the 
histopathological appearance showing characteristic 'Cowdry Type A' inclusions as shown 
below. Choose the correct statements from those below:
questions.explanation:
The given clinical complex describes a case of classic galactosemia in the infant (increased plasma 
galactose and urine galactitol levels) and herpes simplex of the breast in the mother 
(histopathology shown in the image has large multinucleate virus-infected cells with 
typical eosinophilic Cowdry Type A inclusions). Galactosemia is an absolute contraindication to breastfeeding and the child is at risk for E.coli 
sepsis. Herpes lesions on the breast are a relative contraindication to breastfeeding and she is at 
risk for recurrence. 276 
Sold by @itachibot Deficiency of galactose-1-uridyltransferase leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate 
and galactitol causes classic galactosemia. Infants show vomiting, diarrhea, and poor weight gain within 3-4 days of breastfeeding.Jaundice 
and liver dysfunction appear in the first or second week of life. Untreated children may show 
nuclear cataracts (oil-droplet cataract), vitreous hemorrhage, hepatic failure, cirrhosis, ascites, 
splenomegaly, or intellectual disability. The proximal renal tubular disease may also manifest as 
metabolic acidosis, galactosuria, glucosuria, and aminoaciduria. The most common cause of death 
is E.coli sepsis.Acute galactose toxicity is manifested by neurological symptoms Diagnosis is made by genetic or mutational analysis. There will the presence of reducing 
substances in the urine. Elimination of galactose from the diet along with adequate calcium 
supplementation reverses growth failure and renal and hepatic dysfunction.
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 18: A father has noticed that whenever his daughter drinks fruit juice she has multiple episodes 
of vomiting. He reports to you that his daughter is allergic to fruit juice. Which of the 
following enzyme deficiency is likely?
questions.explanation:
Aldolase B deficiency is likely in this child. In the given case scenario, the child becomes symptomatic after ingesting fruit juice that contains 
fructose; this indicates that she has hereditary fructose intolerance, which is caused by the 
deficiency of aldolase B. Deficiency of fructose-1,6- bisphosphate aldolase (Aldolase B hereditary fructose 
intolerance): Fructose aldolase B is present in the liver, kidney, and intestine. It catalyzes the 
hydrolysis of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate into triose phosphate and glyceraldehyde phosphate. Clinical features: Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from 
fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). Clinical features include jaundice, 
hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. It resembles galactosemia. Acute 
ingestion causes symptomatic hypoglycemia. Chronic intake results in failure to thrive and hepatic 
disease. The persistence of fructose intake can lead to liver failure, kidney failure, and death. Diagnosis: Reducing substance is seen in the urine during an episode (Benedict's test +). An 
assay of fructaldolase B activity in the liver gives a definitive diagnosis. Treatment: Complete elimination of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet. 
With age, symptoms become milder even after fructose ingestion. The long-term prognosis is 
good. Note: The deficiency of fructokinase is not associated with any clinical manifestations. Fructosuria is an 
accidental finding usually made because the asymptomatic patient's urine contains a reducing 
substance. No treatment is necessary, and the prognosis is excellent.
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question: Question 19: "Tomcat urine" is characteristically seen in
questions.explanation:
Tomcat urine is characteristically seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency. It is named so because of its peculiar odour. 277 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question: Question 20: The enzyme deficient in hereditary coproporphyria is
questions.explanation:
The enzyme deficient in hereditary coproporphyria is coproporphyrinogen oxidase (CPOX). Hereditary coproporphyria (HCP): • Autosomal-dominant hepatic porphyria is caused by the deficiency of CPOX. • Acute attacks of HCP are treated as in acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), which includes 
intravenous hemin and identifying and avoiding precipitating factors. Cholestyramine may be of 
some value for photosensitivity occurring with liver dysfunction. • Gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogs can be effective for the prevention of cyclic attacks.
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 21: Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase causes 267 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase causes acute intermittent porphyria. Other options: • Porphyria cutanea tarda: Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD) • Variegate porphyria: Deficiency of Protoporphyrinogen oxidase (PPOX) • X-Linked protoporphyria: Gain of function mutation of -aminolevulinate synthase 2 (ALAS2)
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 22: A mother who is a hairstylist has noted that her baby's hair looks dull, breaks off easily, and is 
tufted. She brings the child to you and informs you about the past history of seizures. 
Investigations reveal elevated plasma ammonia levels and argininosuccinate levels. What is 
the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis is argininosuccinic aciduria due to argininosuccinate lyase deficiency. It is accompanied by high levels of argininosuccinate levels in blood, CSF, and urine. It is also 
associated with friable, tufted hair known as trichorrhexis nodosa. Image showing Trichorrhexis nodosa: 278 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole

questions.question:
Question 23: Accumulation of  
 takes place in Farber’s disease.
questions.explanation:
Accumulation of Ceramide is seen in Farber’s disease due to ceramidase deficiency. Clinical features of Farber’s disease : • Painful joint swelling, nodules, progressive joint deformity • Hoarse cry • Breathing difficulty • Failure to thrive 279 
Sold by @itachibot Polio and AIDS
questions.chapter_heading: Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle  Complex Mole
